article.description: Oklahoma State used a late run to avoid another first-round stumble.
article.headline: Cowboys reel off final 10 points to defeat Penn
article.linkText: Cowboys avoid another early exit with late run
article.story:
BOSTON (AP) -- Eddie Sutton turned himself into a "junkyard dog'' to turn things around for Oklahoma State. Even grumpier than usual after the Cowboys lost eight of their last 12 games, Sutton put his team through two-a-day practices while their classmates were on spring break. The message was clear: He did not want a third consecutive first-round loss in the NCAA Tournament.
Dick Vitale: What a battle between the Cowboys and the Quakers! The final score was not indicative of how tough this game was, as Eddie Sutton's OSU team pulled away late in the second half. More
Victor Williams scored a career-high 29 points Friday to lead Oklahoma State to a 77-63 victory over Penn in the first round of the East Regional. "We had a meeting before we took the floor and all the seniors said, 'We can't leave this program without giving coach Sutton a win,''' Williams said. "I could see it in everyone's eyes. Down the stretch, we just made everything happen.'' Ugonna Onyekwe matched a career high with 30 points for Penn, which won its previous 15 games and went undefeated in the Ivy League. The Quakers (22-6) were within four with 2:58 left, but they gave up the last 10 points of the game. Oklahoma State (22-9) will play Sunday against Syracuse, which beat Manhattan 76-65. And it's a good bet that on Saturday, Sutton will be leading his players through one of the workouts that led Williams to start calling him "junkyard dog.'' "I'm not nearly as hard or as tough as I used to be,'' Sutton said. One of the most successful coaches in the history of the tournament, with 24 appearances, Sutton was the first coach to take four different teams to the NCAAs. He led Oklahoma State to the Final Four in 1995 and the round of eight in 2000, but he hasn't had much luck with this team. The Cowboys lost in the first round to Southern Cal in 2001 and Kent State in '02. That's why Sutton turned up the pressure on his team after they ended the season with losses in four of their last five games. "We were making too many mistakes,'' Sutton said. "We didn't play very well the last month of the year.'' Getting out of the powerful Big 12 conference -- home to six tournament teams and two No. 1 seeds -- was more to their liking. Ivan McFarlin had 13 points and 12 rebounds, Tony Allen scored eight consecutive points during a key second-half run and the Cowboys made just enough free throws to win. Although they missed four straight from the line in the second half, they made the next five to pull away from the Quakers. The Ivy League has won just three games in the NCAA Tournament since 1984, but that doesn't mean its teams have gone away quietly. Penn last won an NCAA game in 1994, when the Quakers beat Nebraska as an 11th seed before losing to Florida. Princeton upset UCLA in 1996 and, as a fifth seed in '98, the Tigers beat UNLV. And that's not counting the stunning, 50-49 loss to top-seeded Georgetown in 1989; no 16th seed has ever beaten a No. 1. Since then, the Ivy League has not been saddled with a 16th seed. Penn, which has represented the conference four of the last five years, led by as many as five points, 29-24, with 4:42 left in the first half. Oklahoma State was down 35-32 when Williams hit a 3-pointer to tie it. With 2.4 seconds left in the half, Penn was called for too many men on the court. Williams made one free throw to give Oklahoma State a 36-35 lead, and the Cowboys never trailed again. "My abacus got stuck,'' Penn coach Fran Dunphy said. "You don't see that happen very often,'' Sutton said. "So even the Ivy Leaguers, I guess, can make mistakes.'' Penn was down 65-61 after Koko Archibong hit two free throws. Williams answered on a give-and-go with McFarlin with 3:06 left, and Andrew Toole made two free throws for the Quakers -- their last points of the game. With 7:53 left, Penn guard Tim Begley stepped on a defender's foot and twisted his left ankle. He needed to be helped off the court, hopping on his right leg while holding his left in the air. He returned for the final minutes and sat on the bench with his shoe off, his foot on a chair and his leg wrapped in ice.
